rm_classifier.prepare_data module

Functions for Preparing and Normalizing Data for UMAP Classification

Author: Johann Luca Kastner Date: 15/09/2025 License: MIT

rm_classifier.prepare_data.find_bin(frequency, freq_bins)[source]

Find the bin index of a given frequency in a list of frequency bins.

Parameters:

  • frequency (float) – The frequency to find.

  • freq_bins (array-like) – The array of frequency bins.

Returns:

The index of the bin closest to the given frequency.

Return type:

int

rm_classifier.prepare_data.cut_beacon_frequency_spectra(spectra, beacon_frequencies, freq_bins=None, peak_width=3)[source]

Cut the spectra around the beacon frequencies.

Parameters:

  • spectra (numpy.ndarray) – The spectral data

  • beacon_frequencies (list or array) – Frequencies to cut out

  • freq_bins (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Frequency bins used in the spectra

  • peak_width (int or list, optional) – Width of the peak(s) to cut. If a list, must be the same length as beacon_frequencies.

Returns:

The spectra with the beacon frequencies cut out.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

rm_classifier.prepare_data.cut_beacon_frequency_timeseries(signal, beacon_frequencies, freq_bins=None, peak_width=3)[source]

Cut the time series around the beacon frequencies using the hard cuts in the fft spectra.

Parameters:

  • signal (numpy.ndarray) – The time series data

  • beacon_frequencies (list or array) – Frequencies to cut out

  • freq_bins (numpy.ndarray, optional) – Frequency bins used in the FFT of the time series

  • peak_width (int or list, optional) – Width of the peak(s) to cut. If a list, must be the same length as beacon_frequencies.

Returns:

The time series with the beacon frequencies cut out.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

rm_classifier.prepare_data.calculate_n_frequency_bins(input_data_type, len_input_data, suppress_dc=False)[source]

Calculate the number of frequency bins and time bins based on the input data type and length.

Parameters:

  • input_data_type (str) – Type of the input data. Must be one of ‘fft’, ‘time’, ‘fft_phase’, or ‘fft_time’.

  • len_input_data (int) – Length of the input data (number of columns).

  • suppress_dc (bool) – Whether the DC component is suppressed.

Returns:

(n_fft, n_time) where n_fft is the number of frequency bins and n_time is the number of time bins.

Return type:

tuple

rm_classifier.prepare_data.denoiser(data, n_rolling_average=10, n_peak=3, n_fft=None)[source]

Remove statistical noise from the data using a rolling average, without smoothing out peaks.

Parameters:

  • data (numpy.ndarray) – The input data to be denoised.

  • n_rolling_average (int) – Number of bins for the rolling average.

  • n_peak (int) – Number of bins for the peak, which are excluded from the rolling average calculation.

  • n_fft (int, optional) – Number of frequency bins. If None, it is set to the number of columns in data.

Returns:

The denoised data.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

rm_classifier.prepare_data.welch_abs_fft(input_time_trace, params)[source]

Calculate the absolute FFT of the input time trace using either standard FFT or Welch’s method.

Parameters:

  • input_time_trace (numpy.ndarray) – The input time trace data.

  • params (dict) –

    Dictionary containing parameters for the FFT calculation, including:

    -** “spectrum_filter”: Method to use for FFT calculation. Must be either None or “welch”. -** “sampling_frequency”: Sampling frequency of the input time trace. -** “welch_nperseg”: Length of each segment for Welch’s method. -** “welch_window”: Type of window to use for Welch’s method. -** “welch_average”: Method to use for averaging in Welch’s method. -** “welch_noverlap”: Number of overlapping points between segments for Welch’s method.

Returns:

The absolute FFT of the input time trace.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

rm_classifier.prepare_data.prepare_data(umap_classifier, data, verbose=True)[source]

Prepare the data according to the specifications in the umap_classifier object. This includes cutting beacon frequencies, applying window functions, converting data types, suppressing DC components, applying denoising and log filters.

Parameters:

  • umap_classifier (_umap_classifier_) – An umap_classifier object containing data preparation specifications.

  • data (numpy.ndarray) – The input data to be prepared.

  • verbose (bool) – Whether to print progress messages.

Returns:

The prepared data.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

rm_classifier.prepare_data.normalize_data(umap_classifier, data, verbose=True)[source]

Normalize the data using the mean and standard deviation from the training data. If the mean and std are not provided, they are calculated from the provided data.

Parameters:

  • umap_classifier (_umap_classifier_) – An umap_classifier object containing normalization specifications.

  • data (numpy.ndarray) – The input data to be normalized.

  • verbose (bool) – Whether to print progress messages.

Returns:

(normalized_data, params) where normalized_data is the normalized data and params is the updated data preparation parameters.

Return type:

tuple

rm_classifier.prepare_data.pooling_data(umap_classifier, data, verbose=True)[source]

Apply pooling to the data according to the specifications in the umap_classifier object.

Parameters:

  • umap_classifier (_umap_classifier_) – An umap_classifier object containing pooling specifications.

  • data (numpy.ndarray) – The input data to be pooled.

  • verbose (bool) – Whether to print progress messages.

Returns:

The pooled data.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray
